conclusion: Analyze forces acting on the suitcase and use conditions for equilibrium.
Forces acting on the suitcase are weight, normal force, frictional force, and pull force.
Weight of the suitcase is G = mg, where m = 15 kg and g = 10 m/s², so G = 150 N.
Normal force is N.
Frictional force is f = μN.
Pull force F has components in vertical and horizontal directions.
Vertical component of pull force is F sin θ.
Horizontal component of pull force is F cos θ.
For uniform movement, net force in vertical and horizontal directions must be zero.
Vertical force balance: N + F sin θ = G, rearrange to N = G - F sin θ.
Horizontal force balance: f = μN = F cos θ, substitute N = G - F sin θ.
Substitute N into f equation: μ(G - F sin θ) = F cos θ.
Rearrange for F: μG - μF sin θ = F cos θ.
Further rearrange: μG = F (cos θ + μ sin θ), F = μG / (cos θ + μ sin θ).
Minimum pull force F is 90 N, substitute F = 90 N and G = 150 N.
Equation becomes 90 (cos θ + μ sin θ) = 150 μ.
Rearrange: 3 cos θ / 5μ + 3 sin θ / 5 = 1.
Multiply through by 5: 3 cos θ / μ + 3 sin θ = 5.
Rearrange for μ: μ = 3 (cos θ + sin θ) / 5.
Determine θ using minimum pull force condition and solve for θ.
Substitute N = 150 - 90 sin θ into frictional force equation.
Equation becomes μ (150 - 90 sin θ) = 90 cos θ.
